snippet: Paralyzed rodents learned to walk again after intensive training and electrical stimulation of the brain and the spine, scientists reported, and work to test the techniques in humans is under way.
abstract: Study published online in journal Science shows that rats with spinal cord injuries that left their hind legs completely paralyzed learned to walk again on their own after an intensive training course that included electrical stimulation of the brain and the spine; findings offer new hope for what until recently few scientists thought possible: complete rehabilitation after a disabling blow to the spinal cord.
lead_paragraph: Paralyzed rodents learned to walk again after intensive training and electrical stimulation of the brain and the spine, scientists reported, and work to test the techniques in humans is under way.

headline.main: In Rat Experiment, New Hope for Spine Injuries
headline.print_headline: In Rat Experiment, New Hope for Spine Injuries
